articles.headline: Bridling at Insulin’s Cost, States Push for Generics
articles.snippet: In the face of an epidemic of diabetes, 11 governors are asking why there is no cheaper generic version of insulin.
articles.abstract: In the face of an epidemic of diabetes, 11 governors are asking why there is no cheaper generic version of insulin.
articles.lead_paragraph: As they examine their state health care budgets, 11 of the nation’s governors have identified one big-ticket item they think should cost less: insulin.

articles.headline: G.M. Sees China, and the Chinese, in a Chevrolet
articles.snippet: How G.M. will fare as Toyota passes it in market share may depend on how it performs in China, its second-largest market after the U.S.
articles.abstract: How G.M. will fare as Toyota passes it in market share may depend on how it performs in China, its second-largest market after the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANTAI, China — Yang Luzhou, who lives here in an industrial town facing North Korea across the bay, is about as far as can be from Americana.

articles.headline: Digital Billboard Up Ahead: New-Wave Sign or Hazard?
articles.snippet: Billboard companies are adopting digital technology that rotates advertiser images every six or eight seconds — the better to catch the eye.
articles.abstract: Billboard companies are adopting digital technology that rotates advertiser images every six or eight seconds — the better to catch the eye.
articles.lead_paragraph: Their very name once told it all: a board to post notices or advertisements. But billboards are getting a makeover.

articles.headline: Unfilled City Manager Posts Hint at Future Gap
articles.snippet: Fractious politics and the limits of small-town life and pay are making the job of city manager harder to fill.
articles.abstract: Fractious politics and the limits of small-town life and pay are making the job of city manager harder to fill.
articles.lead_paragraph: TECUMSEH, Okla. — Bent over a yellow 1969 Camaro Super Sport, David Johnson said he much preferred restoring muscle cars to solving his neighbors’ utility and garbage woes as Tecumseh’s city manager.

articles.headline: For $7.93 an Hour, It’s Worth a Trip Across a State Line
articles.snippet: In Washington State, the minimum wage is 54 percent higher than in Idaho. Businesses at the dividing line are a real-life laboratory for the effects of an increase.
articles.abstract: In Washington State, the minimum wage is 54 percent higher than in Idaho. Businesses at the dividing line are a real-life laboratory for the effects of an increase.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIBERTY LAKE, Wash., Jan. 9 — Just eight miles separate this town on the Washington side of the state border from Post Falls on the Idaho side. But the towns are nearly $3 an hour apart in the required minimum wage. Washington pays the highest in the nation, just under $8 an hour, and Idaho has among the lowest, matching 21 states that have not raised the hourly wage beyond the federal minimum of $5.15.

articles.headline: Apple Waves Its Wand at the Phone
articles.snippet: The new iPhone is so packed with possibilities that the cellphone may actually be the least interesting part.
articles.abstract: The new iPhone is so packed with possibilities that the cellphone may actually be the least interesting part.

articles.headline: A New Focus on Delta Air as Deal Bait
articles.snippet: US Airways increased its bid for Delta to about $10.3 billion. Hours later, Northwest Airlines emerged as a potential suitor.
articles.abstract: US Airways increased its bid for Delta to about $10.3 billion. Hours later, Northwest Airlines emerged as a potential suitor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines, in such dire straits a year ago that its chief financial officer called it “a company I’m not sure we could have given away,” is suddenly in great demand.

articles.headline: Firms Fret as Office E-Mail Jumps Security Walls
articles.snippet: More Internet-literate workers are forwarding their office e-mail to free Web-accessible personal accounts.
articles.abstract: More Internet-literate workers are forwarding their office e-mail to free Web-accessible personal accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10  Companies spend millions on systems to keep corporate e-mail safe. If only their employees were as paranoid.

articles.headline: Bush Adds Troops in Bid to Secure Iraq
articles.snippet: President Bush conceded for the first time that there had not been enough American or Iraqi troops in Baghdad to halt the capital’s descent over the past year into chaos.
articles.abstract: President Bush conceded for the first time that there had not been enough American or Iraqi troops in Baghdad to halt the capital’s descent over the past year into chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — President Bush embraced a major tactical shift on Wednesday evening in the war in Iraq when he declared that the only way to quell sectarian violence there was to send more than 20,000 additional American troops into combat.

articles.headline: Lawyer Gave Information to Kerkorian
articles.snippet: Recordings show how information from private detective Anthony Pellicano could affect a high-stakes lawsuit involving the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian.
articles.abstract: Recordings show how information from private detective Anthony Pellicano could affect a high-stakes lawsuit involving the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 — When Kirk Kerkorian’s longtime lawyer was indicted on wiretapping and conspiracy charges last February in the federal investigation of the Hollywood private detective Anthony Pellicano, the billionaire investor was mentioned almost as an afterthought.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Allison Hope Weiner
